awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Meteor Plasma Formation and Dynamics with Implication for Radar Measurements
awd_abstract_narration:
Earth's upper atmosphere is densely populated by molecular, atomic and ionized meteors. These particles are important for maintaining the conductivity of the E region ionosphere (~90-150 km). They can be sensed using radio and optical methods, and therefore provide a great deal of information about the state of the upper atmosphere and the extraterrestrial environments of their origin. However, current estimates of total meteoric input are accurate only to within approximately two orders of magnitude. It is important to improve upon such estimates, since meteor chemistry affects Earth from roughly 150 km above the surface all the way down to the ice cores. 

The research will apply radar data and first-principles computer models to trace the evolution of meteor plasma in the ionosphere. The project will support a full-time graduate student and an undergraduate. The Principal Investigators (PIs)' work will yield knowledge of the types of meteors that contribute most to Earth's upper atmosphere. This information is important to Space scientists, engineers, and astronomers. Spacecraft designers need to know the distribution of particle orbits and masses in order to mitigate potential hazards. Meteor population characteristics provides greater understanding of the evolution and composition of the outer solar system. The PIs and co-PI will continue their efforts to share their knowledge and enthusiasm about space and meteor science with the larger community through outreach to K-12 schools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project research was developed in four major directions: (1) modeling of the explosive evaporation of meteoroids due to erosive impacts of atmospheric particles; (2) theory and simulations of head plasma formation; (3) simulations of radar wave scattering from the head plasma; (4) analysis of 3D kinetic simulations of the plasma trails.
    (1) Using molecular dynamics simulator LAMMPS, we have performed first atomic scale modeling of the initial stage of ablation when hypersonic collisions between the meteoroid and atmospheric particles cause the direct ejection of atoms from the meteoroid surface. The new simulation results lead to changes in the expected electron line densities, visual magnitudes of meteoroids, and to the prediction that meteoroids ablate a few kilometers lower than previously thought. This affects analysis of radar and visual measurements, as well as determination of the meteoroid mass.
    (2) We have performed 3-D collisional particle-in-cell (PIC) simulations of the meteor head plasma responsible for the radar head echo. Obtaining the meteoroid mass from head echo radar cross section depends on the assumed plasma density distribution around the meteoroid. An analytical model developed earlier by our group and previous simulations suggest that the plasma density distribution differs dramatically from the spherically symmetric Gaussian distribution used to calculate meteoroid masses in a number of previous studies. The improved results of new PIC simulations of the head echo plasma with including electric and magnetic fields, have shown that these fields change the ion density distribution by less than ∼ 2% in the meteor head echo region, but the electron density distribution changes by up to tens of percent depending on the location, electron energies, and magnetic field orientation with respect to the meteoroid path.
    (3) Using these and previous results, we have performed finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) simulations of electromagnetic waves scattering off meteor head plasma. We have used the FDTD simulation results to fit a model that relates the meteoroid ablation rate to the head echo radar cross section (RCS), and show that the RCS of plasma distributions derived from the analytical model and PIC simulations reasonably well agree. The power-law model yields more accurate meteoroid mass estimates than did previous methods.
    (4) Radars detect plasma trails created by small meteoroids on the upper atmosphere. Researchers use models to investigate the dynamic evolution of the trails, enabling them to better interpret radar results. We employed a fully kinetic, three-dimensional code to explore the effects of the trail characteristics. The simulations characterize the turbulence that develops as the trail evolves and these are compared to radar data. The finite trail simulations demonstrate that the bulk motion of the plasma trail flows with the neutral wind. A detailed analysis yields spectral widths and other important characteristics. These results will allow researchers to draw more detailed and accurate information from nonspecular radar observations of meteors.
    We have published our research in peer-reviewed papers and presented its results at multiple conferences and workshops. A number of graduate and undergraduate students, including women, had been involved in the research project. As a result, the students acquired important research and computational skills that advanced their knowledge and may be crucial in their further career. A number of theoretical models and computer techniques developed in the course of the project can be successfully applied to fields beyond the project research discipline..
